segment.source: Plan for AppLocker policy management (Windows 10)
segment.target: Plan for AppLocker policy management (Windows 10)

segment.source: This topic for describes the decisions you need to make to establish the processes for managing and maintaining AppLocker policies.
segment.target: This topic for describes the decisions you need to make to establish the processes for managing and maintaining AppLocker policies.

segment.source: Plan for AppLocker policy management
segment.target: Plan for AppLocker policy management

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: This topic for describes the decisions you need to make to establish the processes for managing and maintaining AppLocker policies.
segment.target: This topic for describes the decisions you need to make to establish the processes for managing and maintaining AppLocker policies.

segment.source: Policy management
segment.target: Policy management

segment.source: Before you begin the deployment process, consider how the AppLocker rules will be managed.
segment.target: Before you begin the deployment process, consider how the AppLocker rules will be managed.

segment.source: Developing a process for managing AppLocker rules helps assure that AppLocker continues to effectively control how applications are allowed to run in your organization.
segment.target: Developing a process for managing AppLocker rules helps assure that AppLocker continues to effectively control how applications are allowed to run in your organization.

segment.source: Application and user support policy
segment.target: Application and user support policy

segment.source: Developing a process for managing AppLocker rules helps assure that AppLocker continues to effectively control how applications are allowed to run in your organization.
segment.target: Developing a process for managing AppLocker rules helps assure that AppLocker continues to effectively control how applications are allowed to run in your organization.

segment.source: Considerations include:
segment.target: Considerations include:

segment.source: What type of end-user support is provided for blocked applications?
segment.target: What type of end-user support is provided for blocked applications?

segment.source: How are new rules added to the policy?
segment.target: How are new rules added to the policy?

segment.source: How are existing rules updated?
segment.target: How are existing rules updated?

segment.source: Are events forwarded for review?
segment.target: Are events forwarded for review?

segment.source: Help desk support
segment.target: Help desk support

segment.source: If your organization has an established help desk support department in place, consider the following when deploying AppLocker policies:
segment.target: If your organization has an established help desk support department in place, consider the following when deploying AppLocker policies:

segment.source: What documentation does your support department require for new policy deployments?
segment.target: What documentation does your support department require for new policy deployments?

segment.source: What are the critical processes in each business group both in work flow and timing that will be affected by application control policies and how could they affect your support department's workload?
segment.target: What are the critical processes in each business group both in work flow and timing that will be affected by application control policies and how could they affect your support department's workload?

segment.source: Who are the contacts in the support department?
segment.target: Who are the contacts in the support department?

segment.source: How will the support department resolve application control issues between the end user and those who maintain the AppLocker rules?
segment.target: How will the support department resolve application control issues between the end user and those who maintain the AppLocker rules?

segment.source: End-user support
segment.target: End-user support

segment.source: Because AppLocker is preventing unapproved apps from running, it is important that your organization carefully plan how to provide end-user support.
segment.target: Because AppLocker is preventing unapproved apps from running, it is important that your organization carefully plan how to provide end-user support.

segment.source: Considerations include:
segment.target: Considerations include:

segment.source: Do you want to use an intranet site as a first line of support for users who have tried to run a blocked app?
segment.target: Do you want to use an intranet site as a first line of support for users who have tried to run a blocked app?

segment.source: How do you want to support exceptions to the policy?
segment.target: How do you want to support exceptions to the policy?

segment.source: Will you allow users to run a script to temporarily allow access to a blocked app?
segment.target: Will you allow users to run a script to temporarily allow access to a blocked app?

segment.source: Using an intranet site
segment.target: Using an intranet site

segment.source: AppLocker can be configured to display the default message but with a custom URL.
segment.target: AppLocker can be configured to display the default message but with a custom URL.

segment.source: You can use this URL to redirect users to a support site that contains information about why the user received the error and which applications are allowed.
segment.target: You can use this URL to redirect users to a support site that contains information about why the user received the error and which applications are allowed.

segment.source: If you do not display a custom URL for the message when an app is blocked, the default URL is used.
segment.target: If you do not display a custom URL for the message when an app is blocked, the default URL is used.

segment.source: The following image shows an example of the error message for a blocked app.
segment.target: The following image shows an example of the error message for a blocked app.

segment.source: You can use the Set a support web link policy setting to customize the More information link.
segment.target: You can use the Set a support web link policy setting to customize the More information link.

segment.source: applocker blocked application error message
segment.target: applocker blocked application error message

segment.source: For steps to display a custom URL for the message, see Display a custom URL message when users try to run a blocked app.
segment.target: For steps to display a custom URL for the message, see Display a custom URL message when users try to run a blocked app.

segment.source: AppLocker event management
segment.target: AppLocker event management

segment.source: Each time that a process requests permission to run, AppLocker creates an event in the AppLocker event log.
segment.target: Each time that a process requests permission to run, AppLocker creates an event in the AppLocker event log.

segment.source: The event details which file tried to run, the attributes of that file, the user that initiated the request, and the rule GUID that was used to make the AppLocker execution decision.
segment.target: The event details which file tried to run, the attributes of that file, the user that initiated the request, and the rule GUID that was used to make the AppLocker execution decision.

segment.source: The AppLocker event log is located in the following path: Applications and Services LogsMicrosoftWindowsAppLocker.
segment.target: The AppLocker event log is located in the following path: Applications and Services LogsMicrosoftWindowsAppLocker.

segment.source: The AppLocker log includes three logs:
segment.target: The AppLocker log includes three logs:

segment.source: EXE and DLL.
segment.target: EXE and DLL.

segment.source: Contains events for all files affected by the executable and DLL rule collections (.exe, .com, .dll, and .ocx).
segment.target: Contains events for all files affected by the executable and DLL rule collections (.exe, .com, .dll, and .ocx).

segment.source: MSI and Script.
segment.target: MSI and Script.

segment.source: Contains events for all files affected by the Windows Installer and script rule collections (.msi, .msp, .ps1, .bat, .cmd, .vbs, and .js).
segment.target: Contains events for all files affected by the Windows Installer and script rule collections (.msi, .msp, .ps1, .bat, .cmd, .vbs, and .js).

segment.source: Packaged app-Deployment or Packaged app-Execution, contains events for all Universal Windows apps affected by the packaged app and packed app installer rule collection (.appx).
segment.target: Packaged app-Deployment or Packaged app-Execution, contains events for all Universal Windows apps affected by the packaged app and packed app installer rule collection (.appx).

segment.source: Collecting these events in a central location can help you maintain your AppLocker policy and troubleshoot rule configuration problems.
segment.target: Collecting these events in a central location can help you maintain your AppLocker policy and troubleshoot rule configuration problems.

segment.source: Event collection technologies such as those available in Windows allow administrators to subscribe to specific event channels and have the events from source computers aggregated into a forwarded event log on a Windows Server operating system collector.
segment.target: Event collection technologies such as those available in Windows allow administrators to subscribe to specific event channels and have the events from source computers aggregated into a forwarded event log on a Windows Server operating system collector.

segment.source: For more info about setting up an event subscription, see Configure Computers to Collect and Forward Events.
segment.target: For more info about setting up an event subscription, see Configure Computers to Collect and Forward Events.

segment.source: Policy maintenance
segment.target: Policy maintenance

segment.source: As new apps are deployed or existing apps are updated by the software publisher, you will need to make revisions to your rule collections to ensure that the policy is current.
segment.target: As new apps are deployed or existing apps are updated by the software publisher, you will need to make revisions to your rule collections to ensure that the policy is current.

segment.source: You can edit an AppLocker policy by adding, changing, or removing rules.
segment.target: You can edit an AppLocker policy by adding, changing, or removing rules.

segment.source: However, you cannot specify a version for the policy by importing additional rules.
segment.target: However, you cannot specify a version for the policy by importing additional rules.

segment.source: To ensure version control when modifying an AppLocker policy, use Group Policy management software that allows you to create versions of Group Policy Objects (GPOs).
segment.target: To ensure version control when modifying an AppLocker policy, use Group Policy management software that allows you to create versions of Group Policy Objects (GPOs).

segment.source: An example of this type of software is the Advanced Group Policy Management feature from the Microsoft Desktop Optimization Pack.
segment.target: An example of this type of software is the Advanced Group Policy Management feature from the Microsoft Desktop Optimization Pack.

segment.source: For more info about Advanced Group Policy Management, see Advanced Group Policy Management Overview (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=145013).
segment.target: For more info about Advanced Group Policy Management, see Advanced Group Policy Management Overview (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=145013).

segment.source: Caution: You should not edit an AppLocker rule collection while it is being enforced in Group Policy.
segment.target: Caution: You should not edit an AppLocker rule collection while it is being enforced in Group Policy.

segment.source: Because AppLocker controls what files are allowed to run, making changes to a live policy can create unexpected behavior.
segment.target: Because AppLocker controls what files are allowed to run, making changes to a live policy can create unexpected behavior.

segment.source: New version of a supported app
segment.target: New version of a supported app

segment.source: When a new version of an app is deployed in the organization, you need to determine whether to continue to support the previous version of that app.
segment.target: When a new version of an app is deployed in the organization, you need to determine whether to continue to support the previous version of that app.

segment.source: To add the new version, you might only need to create a new rule for each file that is associated with the app.
segment.target: To add the new version, you might only need to create a new rule for each file that is associated with the app.

segment.source: If you are using publisher conditions and the version is not specified, then the existing rule or rules might be sufficient to allow the updated file to run.
segment.target: If you are using publisher conditions and the version is not specified, then the existing rule or rules might be sufficient to allow the updated file to run.

segment.source: You must ensure, however, that the updated app has not altered the file names or added files to support new functionality.
segment.target: You must ensure, however, that the updated app has not altered the file names or added files to support new functionality.

segment.source: If so, then you must modify the existing rules or create new rules.
segment.target: If so, then you must modify the existing rules or create new rules.

segment.source: To continue to reuse a publisher-based rule without a specific file version, you must also ensure that the file's digital signature is still identical to the previous version—the publisher, product name, and file name (if configured in your rule) must all match for the rule to be correctly applied.
segment.target: To continue to reuse a publisher-based rule without a specific file version, you must also ensure that the file's digital signature is still identical to the previous version—the publisher, product name, and file name (if configured in your rule) must all match for the rule to be correctly applied.

segment.source: To determine whether a file has been modified during an app update, review the publisher's release details provided with the update package.
segment.target: To determine whether a file has been modified during an app update, review the publisher's release details provided with the update package.

segment.source: You can also review the publisher's web page to retrieve this information.
segment.target: You can also review the publisher's web page to retrieve this information.

segment.source: Each file can also be inspected to determine the version.
segment.target: Each file can also be inspected to determine the version.

segment.source: For files that are allowed or denied with file hash conditions, you must retrieve the new file hash.
segment.target: For files that are allowed or denied with file hash conditions, you must retrieve the new file hash.

segment.source: To add support for a new version and maintain support for the older version, you can either create a new file hash rule for the new version or edit the existing rule and add the new file hash to the list of conditions.
segment.target: To add support for a new version and maintain support for the older version, you can either create a new file hash rule for the new version or edit the existing rule and add the new file hash to the list of conditions.

segment.source: For files with path conditions, you should verify that the installation path has not changed from what is stated in the rule.
segment.target: For files with path conditions, you should verify that the installation path has not changed from what is stated in the rule.

segment.source: If the path has changed, you need to update the rule before installing the new version of the app
segment.target: If the path has changed, you need to update the rule before installing the new version of the app

segment.source: Recently deployed app
segment.target: Recently deployed app

segment.source: To support a new app, you must add one or more rules to the existing AppLocker policy.
segment.target: To support a new app, you must add one or more rules to the existing AppLocker policy.

segment.source: App is no longer supported
segment.target: App is no longer supported

segment.source: If your organization has determined that it will no longer support an application that has AppLocker rules associated with it, the easiest way to prevent users from running the app is to delete these rules.
segment.target: If your organization has determined that it will no longer support an application that has AppLocker rules associated with it, the easiest way to prevent users from running the app is to delete these rules.

segment.source: App is blocked but should be allowed
segment.target: App is blocked but should be allowed

segment.source: A file could be blocked for three reasons:
segment.target: A file could be blocked for three reasons:

segment.source: The most common reason is that no rule exists to allow the app to run.
segment.target: The most common reason is that no rule exists to allow the app to run.

segment.source: There may be an existing rule that was created for the file that is too restrictive.
segment.target: There may be an existing rule that was created for the file that is too restrictive.

segment.source: A deny rule, which cannot be overridden, is explicitly blocking the file.
segment.target: A deny rule, which cannot be overridden, is explicitly blocking the file.

segment.source: Before editing the rule collection, first determine what rule is preventing the file from running.
segment.target: Before editing the rule collection, first determine what rule is preventing the file from running.

segment.source: You can troubleshoot the problem by using the Test-AppLockerPolicy Windows PowerShell cmdlet.
segment.target: You can troubleshoot the problem by using the Test-AppLockerPolicy Windows PowerShell cmdlet.

segment.source: For more info about troubleshooting an AppLocker policy, see Testing and Updating an AppLocker Policy (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=160269).
segment.target: For more info about troubleshooting an AppLocker policy, see Testing and Updating an AppLocker Policy (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=160269).

segment.source: Next steps
segment.target: Next steps

segment.source: After deciding how your organization will manage your AppLocker policy, record your findings.
segment.target: After deciding how your organization will manage your AppLocker policy, record your findings.

segment.source: End-user support policy.
segment.target: End-user support policy.

segment.source: Document the process that you will use for handling calls from users who have attempted to run a blocked app, and ensure that support personnel have clear escalation steps so that the administrator can update the AppLocker policy, if necessary.
segment.target: Document the process that you will use for handling calls from users who have attempted to run a blocked app, and ensure that support personnel have clear escalation steps so that the administrator can update the AppLocker policy, if necessary.

segment.source: Event processing.
segment.target: Event processing.

segment.source: Document whether events will be collected in a central location called a store, how that store will be archived, and whether the events will be processed for analysis.
segment.target: Document whether events will be collected in a central location called a store, how that store will be archived, and whether the events will be processed for analysis.

segment.source: Policy maintenance.
segment.target: Policy maintenance.

segment.source: Detail how rules will be added to the policy and in which GPO the rules are defined.
segment.target: Detail how rules will be added to the policy and in which GPO the rules are defined.

segment.source: For information and steps how to document your processes, see Document your application control management processes.
segment.target: For information and steps how to document your processes, see Document your application control management processes.
